FORLORN ISLAND

Now in the boat, the rich purple of late
afternoon setting off against the water,
annoyed at the girl's apprehension. He they moved slowly towards the spot the
map had marked with an elaborate X. In
an hour or so they reached the beach and
proceeded carefully to the overhang of
rocky ledge they sought. Sure enough a
crude wooden door had been wedged into
a niche invisible from any except the secret
approach. Akerly heaved it open and his
mouth sagged in disbelief at the sight of
a great open chest, stuffed with precious
stones and gold coin. This was fantastic!
leaned and pulled rhythmically on the
oars, pleased at the sound they made each
time he lifted them lightly from the water.
The girl squirmed uncomfortably at the
other end of the little boat.
This was the sort of pro ject Akerly
liked.
the village on a particularly dull, sticky
afternoon. Every afternoon on Key Walter
is that way and if you enjoy life it is very
relaxing: if you're in a semi-limbo of irri-
tating inactivity then the stickiness is just
one more thing to focus discontent on.
Akerly was enjoying himself. Rummaging boat."
in a shop which sold nautical relics was
really interesting and his companion
shared his enthusiasm. She was attrac-
tive indeed, her clean presence amidst the
dusty rope and metal giving the shop the
exhilarating breath of life. The shop keep-
er pressed both the girl and Akerly hoping
to convert browsers into customers, if only
for, some trifling item.
It had begun a few days ago in
"Well, it's ours," he laughed. "Don't
look so frightened. Let's get it into the
After much shoving and muttering the
chest was finally stored aft in the rowboat.
In order to get the thing past the wooden
door Akerly had smashed a great earthen
pot that was.in the way. Curious tendrils
of mauve smoke curled in the bottom of
the pot but Akerly took no notice of them.
At least not until he pushed off from shore
and began rowing away.
"Do you like treasure hunts?" he asked.
The smoke issued angrily from the cave
"Never been on one," answered the girl. and quickly assumed some definite form.
Akerly rowed hard unable to convince him-
self his eyes were not playing a trick. A
giant pirate now stood on the beach where
the smoke had been and worst of all the
pirate kept getting larger and larger and
larger! It was the spirit set to guard the
treasure, now coming through the water
towards the little boat in the fury of three
hundred years of waiting!
"I like them," said Akerly, glancing at
the girl.
“Then you're in for a really good one,"
the shopkeeper continued. "I have several
copies of a map which clearly, describes
the location of a fortune in pirate loot
buried on Forlorn Island. Twice before
I sold this map to people who went after
the treasure. Both parties said they lo-
cated it but when I asked them why they
couldn't take it away they mumbled some
nonsense about the Cove being protected
by LaFitte. The map is ten dollars, the
treasure is yours if you can get it out."
"Jump!" shouted Akerly, and jump
they did, overturning the boat and treas-
ure. When they surfaced the pirate was
gone, apparently satisfied that the treasure
was still in
very wet people climbed back into the
righted boat glad to be alive and wanting
nothing more to do with the treasure of
Forlorn Island.

ten dollars as a work of art alone. The
